name: Steam (Gaseous H₂O)
description: Gaseous form of water vapor. Can be invisible at low concentrations (water vapor in air) or visible as a dense white vapor/clouds when near condensation point. Steam is a key state for studying thermodynamics and phase transitions.

specificHeatGas.description: Energy needed to raise 1 gram of steam by 1°C at constant pressure. Lower than both liquid water (4.186) and solid ice (2.09).

heatOfVaporization.description: Energy required to convert liquid water to steam at 100°C. Massive energy requirement is why steam causes severe burns - it releases this energy when condensing on skin.

density.description: Much lower than liquid water (1000 kg/m³). Steam is ~1667 times less dense than liquid water at same temperature, which is why steam rises.

boilingPoint.description: Temperature at which liquid water converts to steam at standard atmospheric pressure. At lower pressures, water boils at lower temperatures.

condensationPoint.description: Temperature at which steam converts back to liquid water. Same as boiling point - phase equilibrium occurs at this temperature.

molecularMass.description: Same as liquid water and ice - H₂O gas molecules have identical mass to condensed phases.

thermalConductivity.description: Much lower than liquid water (0.606) and ice (2.24). Gases conduct heat poorly compared to liquids and solids.

viscosity.description: Much lower than liquid water (0.001 Pa·s). Steam is very thin and flows easily.

compressibility.description: Highly compressible - steam volume changes significantly with pressure changes. Much more compressible than liquids or solids.

dielectricConstant.description: Nearly equal to vacuum/air. Steam does not interact with electric fields the way liquid water (78) does.

saturation.description: Saturated steam: steam in equilibrium with liquid water at the same temperature. Contains maximum water molecules per volume.

superheating.description: Superheated steam: steam heated above its saturation temperature. No longer in equilibrium with liquid. Much hotter and less condensable than saturated steam.
superheating.applications: Turbines in power plants use superheated steam for efficiency

invisibility.description: Water vapor becomes invisible when its partial pressure is below saturation. The white 'steam' visible above boiling water is actually tiny water droplets (condensation), not vapor itself.

coolingModel.description: Newton's Law of Cooling coefficient for steam. Slightly higher than liquid water (0.0015) due to gas dynamics and larger surface-to-mass ratio. Hot steam cools rapidly through convection.

visualProperties.appearance: Invisible when dry/superheated. Visible as white vapor clouds when near saturation and condensing. The 'steam' we see is actually water droplets (aerosol), not the gas itself.

condensationTo.description: Condensation releases massive amounts of heat - why steam burns are so severe

deposition.description: Direct conversion from gas to solid without passing through liquid phase (reverse of sublimation)

equilibriumWithWater.description: At 100°C (at 1 atm pressure), liquid water and steam coexist in equilibrium

enthalpyOfVaporization.description: The latent heat - energy hidden in the form of breaking intermolecular bonds during vaporization

steamTurbines.application: Power generation in thermal power plants
steamTurbines.description: High-pressure superheated steam expands through turbines to generate electricity

pressureTemperatureRelationship.clausius_clapeyron: The Clausius-Clapeyron equation describes how saturation pressure changes with temperature
pressureTemperatureRelationship.consequence: Higher pressure → higher boiling point. Pressure cookers exploit this to cook faster.

atmosphericWaterVapor.concentration: 0-4% by volume depending on temperature and location
atmosphericWaterVapor.role: Absorbs infrared radiation - major greenhouse gas
atmosphericWaterVapor.hydrological: Part of the water cycle - evaporation and precipitation

clouds.composition: Water droplets and ice crystals suspended in air, not water vapor
clouds.formation: Water vapor rises and cools; condenses into visible droplets/crystals when saturation is reached

humidity.relative: Ratio of water vapor pressure to saturation pressure at same temperature
humidity.dew_point: Temperature at which air becomes saturated and condensation begins

precipitation.source: Cloud water droplets and ice crystals that grow and fall as rain or snow

severelyBurns.description: Steam at 100°C causes much worse burns than water at 100°C because condensation releases 2257 kJ/kg of energy directly into tissue
severelyBurns.comparison: A small amount of steam delivers far more heat to skin than equivalent mass of hot water

invisibility.danger: Superheated steam is completely invisible, making it impossible to see the hazard before contact

pressure.description: Confined steam builds up tremendous pressure. Rupturing containment causes violent explosions.

metadata.educationalNotes: Steam is crucial for understanding thermodynamics, phase transitions, and the water cycle. The latent heat of vaporization is enormous compared to sensible heat changes. This is why boiling water takes a long time - most energy goes into vaporization, not temperature increase.
metadata.historicalNote: Steam power revolutionized society during the Industrial Revolution. The development of efficient steam engines transformed manufacturing, transportation, and energy generation. James Watt's improvements to the steam engine made large-scale mechanization possible.
